events.title: Birth
events.summary: Ernest Chausson was born into an affluent bourgeois family in Paris. He was the sole surviving child of a building contractor who contributed to the redevelopment of Paris during the 1850s.
events.fun_version: Ernest Chausson was born into an affluent bourgeois family in Paris as the sole surviving child of a building contractor who contributed to the redevelopment of Paris during the 1850s. He was the last remaining 'trophy child’ and lived a life of luxury. Growing up in the City of Lights, his father was so good at renovations, he could probably convince a crumbling building to sign a lease!

events.title: Education at the Conservatoire
events.summary: At the age of 24, Chausson began attending the composition classes of Jules Massenet at the Paris Conservatoire, earning Massenet's respect as an exceptional person and true artist. He also studied with César Franck, with whom he formed a lasting friendship.
events.fun_version: At just 24, Chausson strutted into the Paris Conservatoire like he owned the place, signing up for composition classes with Jules Massenet. Little did Massenet know he was about to become Chausson's biggest fan – no bias there, right? This exceptional young artist earned Massenet's respect, and not to mention his sidekick César Franck, who quickly learned that being friends with a genius means getting used to an endless supply of musical brilliance.

events.title: Failed Prix de Rome
events.summary: Chausson interrupted his studies in 1881 due to a failed attempt to win the prestigious Prix de Rome, which would have allowed him to further his musical education.
events.fun_version: In 1881, Chausson decided that studying was overrated after he bombed an attempt for the coveted Prix de Rome. He interrupted his studies, thinking who needs a fancy award when you can just chill and compose music at home?

events.title: Visit to Bayreuth
events.summary: Chausson visited Bayreuth in 1882 and 1883 to experience the operas of Richard Wagner. His first trip included attending the premiere of Wagner's Parsifal with Vincent d'Indy, while his second trip featured his new spouse, Jeanne Escudier.
events.fun_version: Chausson, the famous music aficionado, hopped on a time machine (a.k.a. a train) back to the glorious years of 1882 and 1883, landing in the operatic wonderland of Bayreuth. They attended Wagner's Parsifal premiere—it's like attending a concert and getting the encore first! Then, on his second adventure, he brought along his brand new wife, Jeanne Escudier, probably to show her what opera looks like when you’re not just napping through the arias.

events.title: Secretary of the Société Nationale de Musique
events.summary: From 1886 until his death, Chausson served as secretary of the Société Nationale de Musique, hosting various notable artists and composers in his home.
events.fun_version: From 1886 until his death, Chausson served as the dedicated and slightly eccentric secretary of the Société Nationale de Musique, hosting a revolving door of notable artists and composers in his home. Either they loved his questionable snacks or simply wanted to experience his off-key piano skills!

events.title: Incidental Music for La Tempête
events.summary: In December 1888, Chausson employed the celesta for the first time in his incidental music written for a small orchestra for La Tempête, a French translation of Shakespeare's The Tempest.
events.fun_version: In December 1888, Chausson decided to unleash the celesta for the very first time in his incidental music for La Tempête, a French translation of Shakespeare’s The Tempest, showcasing the celesta's delightful presence!

events.title: Beginning of Third Period
events.summary: From his father's death in 1894, Chausson entered his third period, during which he was especially influenced by his reading of symbolist poets and Russian literature, particularly Turgenev, Dostoyevsky, and Tolstoy.
events.fun_version: After his father's unfortunate exit from the stage of life in 1894, Chausson jumped into the ‘I’m-so-influenced-now’ phase, during which he was especially influenced by his reading of symbolist poets and Russian literature like it was a new diet fad.
